What is the purpose of the `estimateconversion` command in Verus?

The `estimateconversion` command in Verus is used to estimate the conversion of a specific amount of one currency to another currency, taking into account conversion fees. It returns an estimated amount out in the destination currency, along with other relevant information.

#### Result ```json {  "inputcurrencyid": iaddress          i-address of source currency  "netinputamount": value            net amount in, after conversion fees in source cu$  "outputcurrencyid": iaddress          i-address of destination currency  "estimatedcurrencyout": value         estimated amount out in destination currency  "estimatedcurrencystate": object        Estimation of all currency values, including pric$ } ```#### Examples: ```bash > verus estimateconversion '{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}' > curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "estimateconversion", "params": ['{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}'] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/ ```### `getbestproofroot '{"proofroots":["version":n,"type":n,"systemid":"currencyidorname","height":n, "stateroot":"hex","blockhash":"hex","power":"hex"],"lastconfirmed":n}'` Determines and returns the index of the best (most recent, valid, qualified) proof root in the list of proof roots, and the most recent, valid proof root.

What information is returned by the `estimateconversion` command?

The `estimateconversion` command returns a JSON object with the following information:

* `inputcurrencyid`: The i-address of the source currency.
* `netinputamount`: The net amount in, after conversion fees in the source currency.
* `outputcurrencyid`: The i-address of the destination currency.
* `estimatedcurrencyout`: The estimated amount out in the destination currency.
* `estimatedcurrencystate`: An estimation of all currency values, including prices.

#### Result ```json {  "inputcurrencyid": iaddress          i-address of source currency  "netinputamount": value            net amount in, after conversion fees in source cu$  "outputcurrencyid": iaddress          i-address of destination currency  "estimatedcurrencyout": value         estimated amount out in destination currency  "estimatedcurrencystate": object        Estimation of all currency values, including pric$ } ```#### Examples: ```bash > verus estimateconversion '{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}' > curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "estimateconversion", "params": ['{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}'] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/ ```### `getbestproofroot '{"proofroots":["version":n,"type":n,"systemid":"currencyidorname","height":n, "stateroot":"hex","blockhash":"hex","power":"hex"],"lastconfirmed":n}'` Determines and returns the index of the best (most recent, valid, qualified) proof root in the list of proof roots, and the most recent, valid proof root.

How can I use the `estimateconversion` command in Verus?

You can use the `estimateconversion` command in Verus through the command line or using a JSON-RPC request. Here are some examples:

* Command line: `verus estimateconversion '{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}'`
* JSON-RPC: `curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "estimateconversion", "params": [{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}]}]' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/`

#### Result ```json {  "inputcurrencyid": iaddress          i-address of source currency  "netinputamount": value            net amount in, after conversion fees in source cu$  "outputcurrencyid": iaddress          i-address of destination currency  "estimatedcurrencyout": value         estimated amount out in destination currency  "estimatedcurrencystate": object        Estimation of all currency values, including pric$ } ```#### Examples: ```bash > verus estimateconversion '{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}' > curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "estimateconversion", "params": ['{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}'] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/ ```### `getbestproofroot '{"proofroots":["version":n,"type":n,"systemid":"currencyidorname","height":n, "stateroot":"hex","blockhash":"hex","power":"hex"],"lastconfirmed":n}'` Determines and returns the index of the best (most recent, valid, qualified) proof root in the list of proof roots, and the most recent, valid proof root.

What is the purpose of the `getbestproofroot` command in Verus?

The `getbestproofroot` command in Verus is used to determine and return the index of the best (most recent, valid, qualified) proof root in a list of proof roots, along with the most recent, valid proof root.

#### Result ```json {  "inputcurrencyid": iaddress          i-address of source currency  "netinputamount": value            net amount in, after conversion fees in source cu$  "outputcurrencyid": iaddress          i-address of destination currency  "estimatedcurrencyout": value         estimated amount out in destination currency  "estimatedcurrencystate": object        Estimation of all currency values, including pric$ } ```#### Examples: ```bash > verus estimateconversion '{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}' > curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "estimateconversion", "params": ['{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}'] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/ ```### `getbestproofroot '{"proofroots":["version":n,"type":n,"systemid":"currencyidorname","height":n, "stateroot":"hex","blockhash":"hex","power":"hex"],"lastconfirmed":n}'` Determines and returns the index of the best (most recent, valid, qualified) proof root in the list of proof roots, and the most recent, valid proof root.
./raw_txt_input/clifaq-02_verus_commands.md
What information do I need to provide to the `getbestproofroot` command?

To use the `getbestproofroot` command, you need to provide a JSON object with the following information:

* `proofroots`: An array of proof roots, each with the following properties:
	+ `version`: The version of the proof root.
	+ `type`: The type of the proof root.
	+ `systemid`: The currency ID or name of the system.
	+ `height`: The height of the proof root.
	+ `stateroot`: The state root of the proof root in hexadecimal format.
	+ `blockhash`: The block hash of the proof root in hexadecimal format.
	+ `power`: The power of the proof root in hexadecimal format.
* `lastconfirmed`: The last confirmed block height.

#### Result ```json {  "inputcurrencyid": iaddress          i-address of source currency  "netinputamount": value            net amount in, after conversion fees in source cu$  "outputcurrencyid": iaddress          i-address of destination currency  "estimatedcurrencyout": value         estimated amount out in destination currency  "estimatedcurrencystate": object        Estimation of all currency values, including pric$ } ```#### Examples: ```bash > verus estimateconversion '{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}' > curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "estimateconversion", "params": ['{"currency":"name","convertto":"name","amount":n}'] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/ ```### `getbestproofroot '{"proofroots":["version":n,"type":n,"systemid":"currencyidorname","height":n, "stateroot":"hex","blockhash":"hex","power":"hex"],"lastconfirmed":n}'` Determines and returns the index of the best (most recent, valid, qualified) proof root in the list of proof roots, and the most recent, valid proof root.
